item.title: Ticket #1285 (WordPress user-agent string missing version number when sending pingback) updated
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1285 (WordPress user-agent string missing version number when sending pingback) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description:
The user agent appears as "WordPress/ PHP/4.3.10". Adding "global $wp_version;" as below in wp-includes/comment-functions.php fixes the issue.

function discover_pingback_server_uri($url, $timeout_bytes = 2048) {

global $wp_version;

item.title: Ticket #1284 (1.5.1 does not post pingbacks sent from 1.5 blogs) updated
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: MC_incubus tells me his 1.5 blog wasn't able to post a PB here due to some fatal error when my WP tried to read his blog entry. He re-uploaded WP and solved the problem. This might be written off as user error, but there's a lot of users, and I'm missing a lot of pingbacks from 1.5 blogs.

item.title: Ticket #1284 (1.5.1 does not post pingbacks sent from 1.5 blogs) updated
item.dc:creator: error
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1284 (1.5.1 does not post pingbacks sent from 1.5 blogs) created
item.dc:creator: error
item.description:
Just what it says: 1.5.1 does not post pingbacks which come from 1.5 sites. It will post pingbacks that come from 1.5.1 sites, and 1.2.2 sites, but not 1.5 sites.

This was duplicated by a single site (IP Address) which has three test blogs: 1.2.2, 1.5 and 1.5.1-2005-04-24, all sending pings to another site (another IP address) running 1.5.1-2005-04-24.

The xmlrpc.log for each on the receiving end indicates nothing untoward; in all three cases the output looks OK. However, with the pingback sent from the 1.5 blog never appears on the site; the other two do appear.

item.title: Ticket #1282 ("All Comments" feed does not include post titles) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
An arguably easier solution would be to fix the_title_rss() to accept a parameter:

function the_title_rss($title = 0) {

$title = get_the_title($title); $title = apply_filters('the_title', $title); $title = apply_filters('the_title_rss', $title); echo $title;

}

Since get_the_title() only uses the global $post object if $title is zero, this should work just fine.

item.title: Ticket #1282 ("All Comments" feed does not include post titles) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1282 ("All Comments" feed does not include post titles) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: It's a pain to hover over a comment's link in my aggregator to see the permalink in order to determine to which post the comment was applied. The supplied patch includes each posts' title in the <title> element when viewing the "all comments" feed.

item.title: Ticket #248 (Links to reference on admin (post) screen should be changeable via ...) updated
item.dc:creator: TigerDE2
item.description:
Status, Resolution, Patch changed

Well, now that 1.5 is out and we're waiting for the next release, I think this might as well be re-opened... :)

Oh, and just to rephrase what I want: Make links on the Admin Centre Write Page "internationalizable", so they can point to localized documentation...

item.title: Ticket #1166 (Pingbacks don't work with allow_url_fopen=Off) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I think the CURL PHP module is the way to go.

The module is available on a lot of hosts, the 'curl' binary isn't (especially in chroot environments). So if you continue to use Snoopy, it should be modified to use the module instead of the binary.

item.title: Ticket #1166 (Pingbacks don't work with allow_url_fopen=Off) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
Dreamhost, which recently disabled remote fopen, is suggesting users use curl. Curl is only used in Snoopy for SSL connections.

We may also want to upgrade snoopy.

item.title: Ticket #1166 (Pingbacks don't work with allow_url_fopen=Off) updated
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: So remote fwrites work even if remote fopen is off?

item.title: Ticket #1280 (Visually Disambiguate Future-Dated Posts) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1280 (Visually Disambiguate Future-Dated Posts) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: The list of posts in the Manage Post screen does not visually disambiguate posts with dates in the future. A color-highlight for these posts would help blog managers scan for published and pending items more quickly.

item.title: Ticket #1279 (smilies fire when you write about RDF) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
actually, the above does NOT solve it: it prevents :Dog to be turned into a smiley, but it introduces a bug in that ;) will no longer be turned into a smiley either. :|

So the bug stands unsolved: the :D in :Dog gets turned into a smiley.

item.title: Ticket #1279 (smilies fire when you write about RDF) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1279 (smilies fire when you write about RDF) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
if you write about:

:Dog rdf:type rdfs:Class :Fido rdf:type :Dog :name rdf:type rdf:Property :Fido :name "Fido" :Dog rdfs:subClassOf :Animal

:Dog triggers a smiley.

To fix, use the following array in vars.php lines 40-89:

if the config file does not provide the smilies array, let's define it here if (!isset($wpsmiliestrans)) {

$wpsmiliestrans = array( '\b:)\b' => 'icon_smile.gif', '\b:D\b' => 'icon_biggrin.gif', '\b:-D\b' => 'icon_biggrin.gif', '\b:grin:\b' => 'icon_biggrin.gif', '\b:)\b' => 'icon_smile.gif', '\b:-)\b' => 'icon_smile.gif', '\b:smile:\b' => 'icon_smile.gif', '\b:(\b' => 'icon_sad.gif', '\b:-(\b' => 'icon_sad.gif', '\b:sad:\b' => 'icon_sad.gif', '\b:o\b' => 'icon_surprised.gif', '\b:-o\b' => 'icon_surprised.gif', '\b:eek:\b' => 'icon_surprised.gif', '\b8O\b' => 'icon_eek.gif', '\b8-O\b' => 'icon_eek.gif', '\b:shock:\b' => 'icon_eek.gif', '\b:?\b' => 'icon_confused.gif', '\b:-?\b' => 'icon_confused.gif', '\b:???:\b' => 'icon_confused.gif', '\b8)\b' => 'icon_cool.gif', '\b8-)\b' => 'icon_cool.gif', '\b:cool:\b' => 'icon_cool.gif', '\b:lol:\b' => 'icon_lol.gif', '\b:x\b' => 'icon_mad.gif', '\b:-x\b' => 'icon_mad.gif', '\b:mad:\b' => 'icon_mad.gif', '\b:P\b' => 'icon_razz.gif', '\b:-P\b' => 'icon_razz.gif', '\b:razz:\b' => 'icon_razz.gif', '\b:oops:\b' => 'icon_redface.gif', '\b:cry:\b' => 'icon_cry.gif', '\b:evil:\b' => 'icon_evil.gif', '\b:twisted:\b' => 'icon_twisted.gif', '\b:roll:\b' => 'icon_rolleyes.gif', '\b:wink:\b' => 'icon_wink.gif', '\b;)\b' => 'icon_wink.gif', '\b;-)\b' => 'icon_wink.gif', '\b:!:\b' => 'icon_exclaim.gif', '\b:?:\b' => 'icon_question.gif', '\b:idea:\b' => 'icon_idea.gif', '\b:arrow:\b' => 'icon_arrow.gif', '\b:|\b' => 'icon_neutral.gif', '\b:-|\b' => 'icon_neutral.gif', '\b:neutral:\b' => 'icon_neutral.gif', '\b:mrgreen:\b' => 'icon_mrgreen.gif', );

}

Bug 1275 has been encountered on other installations of nightlies dating from somewhere around 4-17, as best current estimates are.

The reproducability of this makes this a major issue.

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: astorm
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) created
item.dc:creator: astorm
item.description:
To be able to identify whether a page is child_of another page or a decendent_of another page.

Let's say I have a bunch of pages that has "Articles" page (id=3) as the parent. I use is_page('child_of=3') in my menu/navigation system to highlight that section.
